gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090
gpus.notes: Top-tier GPU with dual 8th-gen NVENC encoders. Can handle 4K streaming and multi-encode scenarios. AV1 hardware encoding available.
common_issues: Overkill for 1080p streaming - consider using AV1 for efficiency
Power draw may cause system instability if PSU is underpowered

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4080
gpus.notes: Excellent streaming GPU with dual NVENC encoders. Perfect for 1440p/4K streaming with AV1 support.
common_issues: High price point - RTX 4070 Ti offers similar streaming performance
16GB VRAM is more than needed for streaming alone

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4070 Ti
gpus.notes: Sweet spot for high-end streaming. Same encoder quality as RTX 4080/4090 at a lower price.
common_issues: 12GB VRAM may limit some 4K workflows
Requires good case airflow

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4070
gpus.notes: Best value for 1080p/1440p streaming with AV1 support. Efficient power consumption.
common_issues: 12GB VRAM limits some multi-tasking scenarios
Not ideal for 4K streaming

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060 Ti
gpus.notes: Solid mid-range choice with full AV1 encoding support. Great for 1080p60 streaming.
common_issues: 8GB VRAM on base model can be limiting
16GB variant recommended for future-proofing

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4060
gpus.notes: Best budget option with AV1 support. Perfect for 1080p streaming on Twitch.
common_issues: 8GB VRAM limits multitasking
Single encoder means no dual-streaming

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080
gpus.notes: Previous-gen flagship with excellent NVENC quality. No AV1, but HEVC works great.
common_issues: No AV1 support - use H.264 or HEVC
Higher power consumption than RTX 40 series

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070
gpus.notes: Excellent 1080p/1440p streaming GPU. Same encoder quality as RTX 3080/3090.
common_issues: No AV1 support
8GB VRAM can be limiting for some games while streaming

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060
gpus.notes: Popular mid-range choice. 12GB VRAM is generous for its tier. Great for 1080p streaming.
common_issues: No AV1 support - stick to H.264
Single encoder setup

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 Super
gpus.notes: Budget-friendly with decent NVENC. Good for 1080p streaming at 6000 Kbps.
common_issues: Older encoder - quality slightly below RTX series
6GB VRAM is limiting for newer games

gpus.name: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650
gpus.notes: Entry-level streaming GPU. Basic NVENC works for 720p-1080p streaming.
common_issues: No HEVC encoding - H.264 only
4GB VRAM severely limits gaming while streaming
Consider upgrading to RTX 4060 for better quality

gpus.name: AMD Radeon RX 7900 XTX
gpus.notes: AMD's flagship with AV1 support. AMF encoder has improved significantly in RDNA 3.
common_issues: AMF quality slightly below NVENC at same bitrate
Requires AMD Software for best encoder settings

gpus.name: AMD Radeon RX 7800 XT
gpus.notes: Great value AMD GPU with full AV1 support. 16GB VRAM is excellent for streaming.
common_issues: AMF requires higher bitrate for equivalent NVENC quality
Some OBS plugins optimized for NVIDIA

gpus.name: AMD Radeon RX 7600
gpus.notes: Budget AMD option with AV1 encoding. Good for 1080p streaming.
common_issues: 8GB VRAM can be limiting
AMF still behind NVENC in quality-per-bitrate

gpus.name: AMD Radeon RX 6700 XT
gpus.notes: Older AMD mid-range. No AV1 but HEVC works. 12GB VRAM is nice.
common_issues: No AV1 support - use H.264
RDNA 2 AMF encoder is weaker than RDNA 3

gpus.name: Intel Arc A770
gpus.notes: Intel's AV1-capable GPU. QSV encoder quality is competitive with improvements.
common_issues: Driver maturity still improving
Some games have compatibility issues
OBS QSV support varies by version
